Loss of bicarbonate-rich fluids from the gastrointestinal tract due to vomiting
Accumulation of ketoacids (acetoacetic acid and β-hydroxybutyric acid) from uncontrolled lipolysis
Retention of inorganic acids (e.g., sulfuric acid) due to acute renal failure

questions.text: A 22-year-old female with Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus is brought to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. She has deep, rapid breathing and her breath has a fruity odor. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.15. Which of the following is the primary pathophysiological mechanism responsible for the observed acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's presentation is a classic description of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), an acute and severe complication of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus.

The fundamental problem is an absolute deficiency of insulin coupled with an excess of counter-regulatory hormones (glucagon, catecholamines, cortisol, growth hormone).

Pathophysiological Sequence Leading to Acidosis:

  • Lipolysis:
    • The lack of insulin and excess glucagon activate hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. T
    • his triggers uncontrolled breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids (FFAs).
  • Hepatic Ketogenesis:
    • The liver is flooded with FFAs. Inside the hepatocytes, these FFAs are oxidized to form acetyl-CoA.
    • The excess acetyl-CoA, which cannot enter the Krebs cycle due to the metabolic milieu, is shunted into the pathway of ketone body synthesis.
  • Ketoacid Production: The three ketone bodies produced are:
    • Acetoacetic acid (a ketoacid)
    • β-hydroxybutyric acid (a hydroxyacid, but treated as a strong acid)
    • Acetone (a neutral compound, responsible for the fruity odor on the breath)
  • Metabolic Acidosis:
    • Acetoacetic acid and β-hydroxybutyric acid are strong organic acids.
    • Their dissociation in the blood releases a high concentration of hydrogen ions (H⁺), overwhelming the body's buffering systems (primarily bicarbonate).
    • This leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, reflected by the low arterial pH (7.15).

Clinical Correlation:

  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul respirations) is a compensatory respiratory alkalosis-the lungs try to blow off CO₂ (an acid) to raise the pH.
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain are direct consequences of the acidosis and hyperketonemia.
  • The fruity odor is from acetone exhaled through the lungs.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

Lactic acid accumulation (Option A): Lactic acidosis can occur in severe DKA due to hypovolemia and poor tissue perfusion. However, it is a secondary contributor, not the primary mechanism. The hallmark and initiating event is ketoacidosis.

Loss of bicarbonate-rich fluids (Option B): Vomiting typically causes a metabolic alkalosis by loss of gastric H⁺ ions. In DKA, vomiting is a symptom of the acidosis, not its cause. The acidosis drives the vomiting, not the other way around.

Retention of inorganic acids (Option D): Renal failure can cause a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to failure to excrete H⁺ and generate new bicarbonate. However, in this young patient with Type 1 DM, the acute presentation points to DKA. Renal function is often preserved initially in DKA, though it may be compromised later due to pre-renal azotemia from dehydration.

choices.text: Increased intracellular glucose concentration due to enhanced facilitated diffusion
Unaffected glucose absorption as it occurs through passive paracellular transport
Reversal of the SGLT-1 transporter, leading to glucose secretion into the lumen
Inhibition of apical glucose uptake via the SGLT-1 transporter due to dissipation of the sodium gradient

questions.text: A research team is studying intestinal absorption using a drug that specifically and completely inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase pump on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes. Which of the following is the most direct and immediate effect of this drug on glucose absorption in the small intestine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Normal mechanism: Intestinal glucose absorption is by secondary active transport: basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase creates a Na⁺ gradient that powers apical SGLT-1; glucose exits basolaterally via GLUT2 by facilitated diffusion.
  • With pump inhibition: The Na⁺ gradient collapses (intracellular Na⁺ rises), so SGLT-1 loses its driving force and apical glucose uptake ceases immediately. Secondarily, intracellular glucose falls and basolateral GLUT2 efflux declines.
  • Role of the Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase Pump (Primary active transport):
    • Located on the basolateral membrane; exports 3 Na⁺ and imports 2 K⁺ per ATP, maintaining:
      • Low intracellular Na⁺ concentration
      • High extracellular (and luminal) Na⁺ concentration
  • Role of the SGLT-1 Transporter (Secondary active transport):
    • Apical Na⁺-glucose symporter that couples downhill entry of 2 Na⁺ to uphill entry of 1 glucose; entirely dependent on the Na⁺ gradient generated by Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase.

Effect of the Inhibitor Drug:

Blocking Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase rapidly dissipates the Na⁺ gradient; SGLT-1 cannot function, so apical glucose uptake stops at once.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

Increased intracellular glucose concentration due to enhanced facilitated diffusion. (Option A): Incorrect- intracellular glucose decreases because SGLT-1 entry stops; GLUT2 mediates facilitated diffusion and does not increase glucose entry.

Unaffected glucose absorption as it occurs through passive paracellular transport. (Option B): Incorrect- physiologic glucose absorption is transcellular via SGLT-1/GLUT2; paracellular flux is minimal and cannot compensate.

Reversal of the SGLT-1 transporter, leading to glucose secretion into the lumen. (Option C): Incorrect- SGLT-1 does not reverse under physiologic conditions; without the Na⁺ gradient it simply fails to transport.

Key Takeaways:

  • Basolateral Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase → Na⁺ gradient → drives apical SGLT-1 glucose uptake; basolateral GLUT2 mediates exit.
  • Inhibiting Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase immediately halts SGLT-1, so apical glucose entry stops.
